clinical_scenarios.title: Acute Abdominal Pain in Elderly Patient

patient_summary.presentation: Acute onset severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

clinical_scenarios.clinical_question: A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began 4 hours ago. The pain is located in the epigastrium and radiates to the back. He has associated nausea and vomiting. Vital signs show BP 90/60, HR 120, temp 100.8°F. What is the most likely diagnosis and immediate management?
key_findings: Severe epigastric pain radiating to back
teaching_points: Acute pancreatitis often presents with epigastric pain radiating to back
Hemodynamic instability suggests severe pancreatitis or alternative diagnosis
CT imaging is diagnostic test of choice for acute pancreatitis
Early aggressive fluid resuscitation is crucial

clinical_scenarios.title: Polypharmacy in Heart Failure Patient
clinical_scenarios.clinical_question: A 68-year-old female with heart failure (EF 30%), diabetes, CKD stage 3, and depression is on multiple medications. Recent labs show worsening kidney function (creatinine 2.1 from 1.8) and hyperkalemia (K+ 5.4). Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, furosemide, metformin, insulin, sertraline, and spironolactone. How would you modify her medication regimen?
medication_adjustments: Hold spironolactone temporarily due to hyperkalemia
Consider switching to insulin-only diabetes management
Monitor potassium closely, consider Kayexalate if needed
teaching_points: ACE inhibitors and aldosterone antagonists can cause hyperkalemia
Heart failure medications need careful titration in CKD

clinical_scenarios.title: Cardiovascular Risk Assessment and Prevention
clinical_scenarios.clinical_question: A 55-year-old male smoker with hypertension and family history of coronary artery disease comes for routine care. He has no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath. Blood pressure is 145/92 on lisinopril 10mg daily. Labs show total cholesterol 220, LDL 145, HDL 38, triglycerides 180. How would you assess his cardiovascular risk and manage prevention?
risk_factors: Hypertension (on treatment but not at goal)
Current smoking (1 pack per day × 20 years)
Family history of premature CAD (father had MI at age 52)
recommendations: Intensive lifestyle counseling for smoking cessation
Increase lisinopril to 20mg daily, target BP <130/80
Consider low-dose aspirin for primary prevention
Lifestyle modifications: diet, exercise, weight management
Follow-up in 3 months to assess response to therapy
teaching_points: Smoking is the most modifiable major risk factor
High-intensity statins reduce MACE by ~25% in primary prevention
Blood pressure goal <130/80 for most adults
Shared decision-making important for aspirin in primary prevention
